title: Image compositing is all you need for data augmentation
author: Ang Jia Ning Shermaine (Imperial College London, U.K.), Michalis Lazarou (University of Surrey, U.K.), Tania Stathaki (Imperial College London, U.K.)
background: Object detection models perform better when trained with diversified datasets, often enhanced through various data augmentation techniques, particularly in scenarios with limited annotated data.
contribution: This paper introduces image compositing as a novel data augmentation technique to improve object detection performance, achieving the highest detection metrics compared to traditional and advanced methods.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods like Generative Adversarial Networks (GANs) and traditional augmentation techniques were less effective due to data distribution shifts and less realistic representations.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves on prior methods by demonstrating that image compositing can create realistic and contextually appropriate images, leading to better model robustness and accuracy.

key_innovation: The method uniquely combines elements from multiple images to generate new synthetic images, focusing on realism and contextual consistency.
real_world_impact: This approach could greatly enhance applications in fields such as security and traffic management, where accurate object detection is crucial.

new_terms.mean Average Precision (mAP): **Mean Average Precision (mAP)** is a popular metric used to evaluate the accuracy of object detection models by measuring the precision-recall trade-off at different threshold levels.
